reviewText:
I'm not too sure what people were expecting with this collection, but from the reviews I hvae read, you people have been far too harsh for what it is and when it was made.

Moto Racer 1 is a PS1 game which, I believe, was ported to the PC (or released at the same time as the PS1 version). The graphics are old and it's going to have the odd glitch and incompatibility now and then. Anyone without common sense should know that your 'Octa core processor with SLI'd GTX 770s' would have compatibility issues with a game from the 90s.

Additionally, you cannot expect a game that was made for the PS1 to be fancy. If a HD remake was produced, the original old-school gamers who played this game probably wouldn't have liked it. Why expect a game or a collection that's released onto Steam to be new and sparkly? Developers ARE allowed to release old games onto Steam.

So overall, I recommend this merely because I congratulate the developers for releasing this great PS1 game onto Steam. I've played all of the games in this collection enough in my childhood and away from Steam to know this deserves a recommendation even if Steam says I've only played for less than an hour.

reviewText:
This is a collection, so be aware that the original games have not been improved upon.
The store page is not ambiguous about that, but I'd rather reiterate because you might have different expectations in this age of HD remakes.
Having loved the original Moto Racer back in the day, a straight port was fine by me, except...

Moto Racer 1 won't launch on my machine -- launcher fails to set colour depth. There might be a way around it, like setting my display to 16-bit manually, but I can't be arsed right now. I might put effort into finding a workaround later though, because I recall this one being my favourite.

Moto Racer 2 does launch, but there's no sound during races, no music or SFX. Plays well, but feels weird because of that.

Moto Racer 3 works (huzzah!). Don't think I played this one back in the day (or not much); it seems less arcadey and fun than the previous two instalments, but that's just my impression after a single race.

Moto Racer 15th anniversary is the most recent entry (you can tell it's modern because you accelerate with the right trigger, not the A button!) and it's utter garbage. Not only does it manage to be uglier than the other, way older entries, but more shamefully it plays poorly. Not the game I cared about anyway, but dang, morbid curiosity is the only reason to bother trying it at all -- and even then I couldn't finish a single lap in a cross race. The way it handles just feels entirely wrong, like someone's first Unity game on XBLIG.

So all in all, if I find a way to make sound work in 2 and for 1 to launch at all, maybe I'll spend some time with this, reminiscing. But I cannot recommend it in good faith.

(Oh, and I spent more than 5 minutes with this -- but Steam only counts time spent in the launcher apparently)

reviewText:
It is unbelieveable, how much crap the people are writing, without getting their stuff fixed themself.
Sorry about that, but it is really necessary to explain everyone, how wrong the negative reviews are!

1. All parts of Moto Racer got controller support! Even the 3rd is playable with the XBOX360 Controller! You can change the controls in every part. From Moto Racer 1 - 3! Just check the configuration settings in the games (or launcher in the 3rd part).

2. There was nowhere written, that this collection is a remake or a HD release, so complaining about that is totally unnecessary! With the right settings and a little engine modding the games look really good!

3. There are no soundbugs at all. The people complaining about that, are just using some random codecpacks, so the game doesn't work right. I got a Realtek HD Onboard Soundcard and no sound problems at all. Everywhere is sound...even in the movies! Config your computers right, then you won't have that problems!

4. The AI is too hard?....NOPE...you are just too weak! Easy AI is easy!

5. The games work like a charm on Win7 x64! No problems, no crashes, no complains! They work even better, then they were on Win95/98/Me

The collection is perfect. If you liked Moto Racer back in the old days, you will feel really nostalgic playing this collection.  I had a smile on my face in every part of the collection. It was like being a child again. Really fun! I will spend more time playing this collection, since it is a really good revive of the good old Moto Racer games! Totally recommending it!

reviewText:
Got this game on the Week long sale on 20/07/2015.

First thing I gotta say, yes, it works. All the games loaded an run. I do agree with other reviews saying that they could have tried to make it more compatible. There are unplayable areas (mostly when you're playing a dirt race with many competitors on screen) and MASSIVE slowdowns... Could be better.

Now the biggest reason for the Negative review: they f*** up Moto Racer 2! Why was the great, perfect soundtrack changed? WHY? I do believe I left Moto Racer's 2 CD more time in my Stereo then in the PC, just for how great the soundtrack is. Then I load the game with high expectations for a battery solo to start the video and I get a totally souless music in a new intro video, and then the menu screen hits and where is the beautiful Punk Rock music? This should be advertised as it is on GOG. I would not have spent not even the less then a dollar I did. Total lack of respect with the game fans.

I suggest mostly playing 1 2 and 3. Leave the remake alone. Pretty sweet though.  10 Bucks is insane though. This should at least be worth 4.50. So yeah. MAJOR nostalgia factor if you can get 1,2 and 3 to work. Ignore the remake. We got it? Good.

reviewText:
The Moto Racer games were a staple of my childhood. The CD for the first game is probably still at my parent's house somewhere. And the games themselves are still reasonably fun, if not very dated.

But this collection is abysmal. It's honestly amazing how lazy this collection is.

First, there's the launcher. The launcher is the laziest part of this collection. It was very obviously made with Windows forms (So I doubt we'll ever see a Mac or Linux port of this), and was made by someone who spent maybe 15 minutes on it. It's just a drop-down menu that lets you pick a game, and sometimes the language. They didn't even change the default icon for goodness' sake! In an hour, I could teach a programmer how to make a better launcher than this...

But let's talk about the games. But with the first Moto Racer, the launcher won't even launch the game! If you go into the installation directory and launche the game there, it will work. But besides the issues with launching the game, it has not been changed. It's just as good as I remember it, but it's controller support has not been updated for modern controllers. Running it with an Xbox 360 controller, the turns are way too fast. You can get used to it, though.

Moto Racer 2 does not allow turning with anything other than a controller for me (Which has aforementioned sensitivity issues). This game is a marked improvment over the first though, even if it's not been changed since it was released.

Moto Racer 3 is the first one so far to run without any issues! It's not as good as Moto Racer 1 or 2 though.

Moto Racer: 15th Anniversary is...there's no way to put this lightly, the worst in the series. It's a port of a mobile game, and it shows: Poor production values; bland and uninspired graphics; and very, very bad AI. There's nothing really enjoyable here.

In all, this is a poor collection of great games. If you want to experience the Moto Racer games, just get them from GOG. If this collection ever gets updated to be less abysmal, I will update this review.

reviewText:
An awesome collection of fun and challenging arcade racers and simulators. These games feature a range of different courses, environments and gameplay types to keep you playing for hours on end!

Whether you want to be racing the GP, blasting time records, performing slick tricks or just blazing through traffic at 300 km/h - these games give you the lot!

Recommended!

reviewText:
Moto Racer (1) crashes as soon as it starts on my x86 laptop.

Moto Racer 2 apparently lets you play up to 4 players at a time, either via the same PC, or through LAN. When playing with the AI, you need to be very mindful about what difficulty you're playing on, and if you're playing on Arcade or Simulation mode. It's fun to race around at the different tracks in the game, and it even lets you make your own tracks, though if you make the corners too tight, it won't let you race in it.

Moto Racer 3 and Moto Racer 15th Anniversary Edition is boring and bland.

Don't buy this compilation, not even on a sale, like I did

reviewText:
MR 2 and 3 both generally work on my system (no sound problems or obvious glitches) but:

MR 2 - XBox 360 controller works good for me, but it's impossible to catch up with the leading few Easy AI riders (at least on a dirt bike). I re-raced the track like 10 times, eventually well enough to compete with what should be Hard mode, and I still couldn't place higher than 5th in the race. The others were gone from the start, never to be seen again, as if their bikes are faster than the player's and they make no mistakes whatsoever.

MR 3 - XBox 360 controller doesn't work. At all. The launcher detects the buttons when I re-map them, but in the game the controller does nothing.

It shows that they threw this thing together quickly.
